At KPMG, like (I imagine) at most companies, we have a custom color palette that presentation and other materials are supposed to conform to. I actually quite like it when things I produce have a consistent look and feel, so I decided to find out how to make a custom color palette in matplotlib. Turns out that it's super easy.

The first step is to create a .mplstyle file for your color scheme. These can contain a bunch of options, but you can download a sample here. Save it as my_style_name.mplstyle. Way down in line 337 (at the time of writing), you will find the following lines:

#axes.prop_cycle    : cycler('color',
#                            ['1f77b4', 'ff7f0e', '2ca02c', 'd62728',
#                              '9467bd', '8c564b', 'e377c2', '7f7f7f',
#                              'bcbd22', '17becf'])
                                            # color cycle for plot lines
                                            # as list of string colorspecs:
                                            # single letter, long name, or
                                            # web-style hex

This setting defines the cycle of colors that matplotlib uses for consecutive elements on plots when you don't specify the colors. Uncomment these lines and swap out the list for a list of your favorite (or corporately imposed) colors. As indicated by the comment, matplotlib will accept single letter, long name, or hex colors. Use the HTML long name colors for full entertainment value.

>>> import matplotlib
>>> matplotlib.get_configdir()
'C:\\Users\\johnpaton\\.matplotlib'
